org.apache.freemarker.core

Interface ParsingConfiguration

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    ParsingAndProcessingConfiguration, TopLevelConfiguration
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Configuration, Configuration.Builder, Configuration.ExtendableBuilder, MutableParsingAndProcessingConfiguration, TemplateConfiguration, TemplateConfiguration.Builder

    public interface ParsingConfiguration
    Implemented by FreeMarker core classes (not by you) that provide configuration settings that affect template parsing (as opposed to (Object, Writer) template processing). New methods may be added any time in future FreeMarker versions, so don't try to implement this interface yourself!
    See Also:
    ProcessingConfiguration, ParsingAndProcessingConfiguration

    • Method Detail

      • getTemplateLanguage

        TemplateLanguage getTemplateLanguage()
        The template language used; this is often overridden for certain file extension with the templateConfigurations setting of the Configuration.

      • isTemplateLanguageSet

        boolean isTemplateLanguageSet()

      • getTagSyntax

        TagSyntax getTagSyntax()
        Determines the syntax of the template files (angle bracket VS square bracket) that has no #ftl in it. The tagSyntax parameter must be one of:
        • TagSyntax.AUTO_DETECT: use the syntax of the first FreeMarker tag (can be anything, like #list, #include, user defined, etc.)
        • TagSyntax.ANGLE_BRACKET: use the angle bracket syntax (the normal syntax)
        • TagSyntax.SQUARE_BRACKET: use the square bracket syntax

        In FreeMarker 2.3.x TagSyntax.ANGLE_BRACKET is the default for better backward compatibility. Starting from 2.4.x TagSyntax.AUTO_DETECT is the default, so it's recommended to use that even for 2.3.x.

        This setting is ignored for the templates that have ftl directive in it. For those templates the syntax used for the ftl directive determines the syntax.

      • isTagSyntaxSet

        boolean isTagSyntaxSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting might returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent parsing configuration or throws a CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getNamingConvention

        NamingConvention getNamingConvention()
        The naming convention used for the identifiers that are part of the template language. The available naming conventions are legacy (directive (tag) names are all-lower-case likethis, others are snake case like_this), and camel case (likeThis). The default is auto-detect, which detects the naming convention used and enforces that same naming convention for the whole template.

        This setting doesn't influence what naming convention is used for the setting names outside templates. Also, it won't ever convert the names of user-defined things, like of data-model members, or the names of user defined macros/functions. It only influences the names of the built-in directives (#elseIf VS elseif), built-ins (?upper_case VS ?upperCase ), special variables (.data_model VS .dataModel).

        Which convention to use: FreeMarker prior to 2.3.23 has only supported NamingConvention.LEGACY, so that's how most templates and examples out there are written as of 2015. But as templates today are mostly written by programmers and often access Java API-s which already use camel case, NamingConvention.CAMEL_CASE is the recommended option for most projects. However, it's no necessary to make a application-wide decision; see auto-detection below.

        FreeMarker will decide the naming convention automatically for each template individually when this setting is set to NamingConvention.AUTO_DETECT (which is the default). The naming convention of a template is decided when the first core (non-user-defined) identifier is met during parsing (not during processing) where the naming convention is relevant (like for s?upperCase or s?upper_case it's relevant, but for s?length it isn't). At that point, the naming convention of the template is decided, and any later core identifier that uses a different convention will be a parsing error. As the naming convention is decided per template, it's not a problem if a template and the other template it #include-s/#import uses a different convention.

        FreeMarker always enforces the same naming convention to be used consistently within the same template "file". Additionally, when this setting is set to non-NamingConvention.AUTO_DETECT, the selected naming convention is enforced on all templates. Thus such a setup can be used to enforce an application-wide naming convention.

        Returns:
        One of the NamingConvention.AUTO_DETECT or NamingConvention.LEGACY or NamingConvention.CAMEL_CASE.

      • isNamingConventionSet

        boolean isNamingConventionSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting might returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent parsing configuration or throws a CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getWhitespaceStripping

        boolean getWhitespaceStripping()
        Whether the template parser will try to remove superfluous white-space around certain tags.

        Overlaps with ProcessingConfiguration.getArithmeticEngine(); the parser needs this for creating numerical literals.

      • getOutputFormat

        OutputFormat getOutputFormat()
        The output format to use, which among others influences auto-escaping (see getAutoEscapingPolicy() autoEscapingPolicy}), and possibly the MIME type of the output.

        On the Configuration level, usually, you should leave this on its default, which is UndefinedOutputFormat.INSTANCE, and then use standard file extensions like "ftlh" (for HTML) or "ftlx" (for XML) (and ensure that recognizeStandardFileExtensions is true; see more there). Where you can't use the standard extensions, templates still can be associated to output formats with patterns matching their name (their path) using the templateConfigurations setting of the Configuration. But if all templates will have the same output format, you may set the outputFormat setting of the Configuration after all, to a value like HTMLOutputFormat.INSTANCE, XMLOutputFormat.INSTANCE, etc. Also note that templates can specify their own output format like <#ftl output_format="HTML">, which overrides any configuration settings.

        See Also:
        Configuration.getRegisteredCustomOutputFormats(), Configuration.getTemplateConfigurations(), getRecognizeStandardFileExtensions(), getAutoEscapingPolicy()

      • isOutputFormatSet

        boolean isOutputFormatSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting might returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent parsing configuration or throws a CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getRecognizeStandardFileExtensions

        boolean getRecognizeStandardFileExtensions()
        Tells if the "file" extension part of the source name (Template.getSourceName()) will influence certain parsing settings. Defaults to true. When true, the following standard file extensions take their effect:
        • ftlh: Sets the outputFormat setting to "HTML" (i.e., HTMLOutputFormat.INSTANCE, unless the "HTML" name is overridden by the registeredOutputFormats setting) and the autoEscapingPolicy setting to AutoEscapingPolicy.ENABLE_IF_DEFAULT.
        • ftlx: Sets the outputFormat setting to "XML" (i.e., XMLOutputFormat.INSTANCE, unless the "XML" name is overridden by the registeredOutputFormats setting) and the autoEscapingPolicy setting to AutoEscapingPolicy.ENABLE_IF_DEFAULT.

        These file extensions are not case sensitive. The file extension is the part after the last dot in the source name. If the source name contains no dot, then it has no file extension.

        The settings activated by these file extensions override the setting values dictated by the templateConfigurations setting of the Configuration.

      • isRecognizeStandardFileExtensionsSet

        boolean isRecognizeStandardFileExtensionsSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting might returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent parsing configuration or throws a CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getIncompatibleImprovements

        Version getIncompatibleImprovements()
        See TopLevelConfiguration.getIncompatibleImprovements(); this is normally directly delegates to Configuration.getIncompatibleImprovements(), and it's always set.

      • getTabSize

        int getTabSize()
        The assumed display width of the tab character (ASCII 9), which influences the column number shown in error messages (or the column number you get through other API-s). So for example if the users edit templates in an editor where the tab width is set to 4, you should set this to 4 so that the column numbers printed by FreeMarker will match the column number shown in the editor. This setting doesn't affect the output of templates, as a tab in the template will remain a tab in the output too. It's value is at least 1, at most 256.

      • isTabSizeSet

        boolean isTabSizeSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting might returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent parsing configuration or throws a CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getSourceEncoding

        Charset getSourceEncoding()
        Sets the charset used for decoding template files.

        Defaults to the default system fileEncoding, which can change from one server to another, so you should always set this setting. If you don't know what charset your should chose, "UTF-8" is usually a good choice.

        When a project contains groups (like folders) of template files where the groups use different encodings, consider using the templateConfigurations setting on the Configuration level.

        Individual templates may specify their own charset by starting with <#ftl sourceEncoding="...">. However, before that's detected, at least part of template must be decoded with some charset first, so this setting (and templateConfigurations) still have role.

      • isSourceEncodingSet

        boolean isSourceEncodingSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting might returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent parsing configuration or throws a CoreSettingValueNotSetException.
